Now this show was a very unique take on the business world. Entrepreneurs (irl) are all just members of this crazy 'other world' which they bet their futures on winning in the 'deals' or fights. Definitely not what i was expecting an anime named C to be about.
But, onto the review: Bear in mind, I watched this all within a 24 hour timespan, so my review may be a bit off due to that.
Story: 9/10
As i stated before, this was a very unique story. I'm very happy about the pacing of the show, every episode seemed to pull you into the next; every episode settingup the next change; every episode bringing up new questions and awnsers. It actually was quite enjoyable to learn about this other world along with the MC. The love affair between MC and his 'asset' was not exactly the most unique, but served its purpose. The only reason I would rate the story NOT a 10 is because near the end, the story posed SO many questions yet never bothers to answer them or even hint at them. Then ultimate ending (while not bad) was somewhat predictable and was awful unfulfilling.


Art: 9/10 (because CGI)

Wow, this show had some nice designs for characters. The humans, while not the prettiest, are each unique and designed typically with their character in mind, which I respect. The 'assets' are where the show really shines in its character designs. Each one was really unique and looked quite good. Everything in the financial district (while sometimes bland af) was really quite amazing to look at and had unique looks to it

Environments were not much to be talked about tbh, the 'real world' (not in financial district) locations were pretty cool, and the art over all was quite good, but the environments in and out of the real world seemed to always lack interest... IDK how else to explain it. 

I understand this was made in 2011, but the CGI really, really, is just bad at times. Or rather, its not bad as in it looks 'bad' but rather sometimes makes the characters limbs and body act really oddly and fake. The CGI environment (which there was quite a bit of in the 'financial district') was.... meh.


Sound: 9/10

This is actually one of my favorite anime OST's. While some of the english lyrics to a couple songs are, without a better explanation, very japanese (and may not make sense), they are still pleasurable to listen to. I think a considerable amount of work was put into this OST.

Voice acting. Japanese i cant really say how good it was, due to me not speaking it, but I will comment on the english acting. There are portions where they lead to the IMF or UN for various story points, and each time the english voice acters seemed so lifeless. This could be because they want clear pronunciations for japanese viewers, but it is a point that must be touched on


Characters 6/10:

Honestly, the MC is forgettable and stereotypical to the isekai genre; the main villian is archetypal and pretty forgettable (Mikuni), honestly from the second he was introduced I could already predict he'd be the final boss (also the OP totally spoiled that for me, but thats OK); the MC's (first  -- second? idk even) girl (Mashu) throughout the series is probably the most developed character. The side villians had some potential, but ultimately the show skipped over them. The main 'good' side that wanted to destroy the 'financial district' (I think Satou?) was actually a decent character and her motivations were decently recognized.  Masakaki fulfilled his 'godlike' role in the series and did quite a good job while at it. Overall though, the MC's other love interest (maybe its my ship idk), Hanabi, really was underdeveloped and the creator seems to have tracked off from their original plan to force a relationship between Mashu and MC.

Basically DEVELOP THE CHARACTERS; MORE MORE MORE DEVELOP; DONT DEVELOP THE VILLIAN AND SIDE CHARACTERS MORE THAN MC.


Overall: 8/10

The character flaws can be overlooked, the bad cgi (at times) can be ignored. Ultimately this show had a really good premise, a nice art team, a dank sound team, but completely average character writers. In the end the majority of the issues I have with this show (beside characters) are really small

[My own notes]
Before I start, I'd like to say that I am not an anime enthusiast. In fact, I rarely have time to watch it, so my choice in anime is very important to me. If I don't like it, I'm quick to drop it, as is evident from my list. If I love it, I'll finish it quickly, but I rarely care enough to voice my opinion on it. That being said, it's somewhat impressive for someone like me to be moved enough to actually write an entire review about something. Take that however you want, but it's the truth.
I will, however, say this:I don't write reviews often, but when I do, I'm very analytic. If you don't want to see this show broken down and dissected to bits and pieces before you've even had a chance to watch it, this is the wrong review for you. If you like that pragmatic, realistic approach to choosing what titles you watch, keep reading.


Warnings aside, it's really difficult these days for an anime, book, show, movie, or any other form of storytelling for that matter to be original. It's a common complaint and I hear it a lot: there's no more originality. But there's actually a reason for this, and a point I've made many times to others: all the great ideas have already been used. It's all about rethinking these ideas and looking at them in a new light. To stand out nowadays you can't just be "original" in the sense that your particular blend of vampire/zombie/werewolf/harem/romance anime hasn't existed in the past, but rather that you can take that idea and make it into something entirely different, something that can't be compared to anything else. People will forget what the show's actually about, simply because your storytelling is so captivating. That's what modern storytelling is about. Take Steins;Gate for example. I know a lot of people didn't like it, but to me, it was an amazing show. There's nothing new about time travelers, paradoxes, conspiracies, moe, and romance, but the exact way that show put it all together, told the story, and developed the characters is what made it so great. And there's nothing new about action, mystery, conspiracy, and "morality" shows either, but C has found a way to make it new regardless. It takes the idea of a super power running things from behind the scenes and turns it into something awesome. The fact that such an old combination of topics and genres could be so enthralling is the reason why I've decided to write this review, and I hope that you too will soon see why as well.  



[Story - 8]

The story is typically the most important part, so I'll start there. When I wrote this review, I wasn't done watching the series yet, so I have a different perspective than most reviewers. 

From my angle, I'm using my past experiences to try and figure out how exactly things are going to pan out. The plot is more or less obvious at this point, though I won't say exactly what it may be. I've watched a lot of different types of anime and TV shows, and can usually spot that professional touch that certain writers have that lets you know it'll have an actual ending. I see that here, and so my hopes are high for this one.


As for the story, it's nothing too original. Broke university student trying to live a normal life. We all can relate to that, and I'm sure that's why the writer chose this character. Why does it matter that we can relate? Because I feel the writer isn't just telling a story, but is trying to warn us of something, or convey a moral. I can't tell exactly what yet, but that's the vibe I'm getting. I generally like these types of shows.

The reason I point that out is because it shows the integrity behind the story. Though it may twist, turn, and fall off into different side paths, it still has a single theme tying it all together, and that's what keeps the plot moving. In a way, it could be compared to the episodic nature of Cowboy Bebop, though the over arching story line is definitely prevalent in the filler-less series of C. While Bebop never seemed to have a definite plot up until the end, there was still a sense that everything was happening for a reason (aside from the fillers) throughout the entire series. That's what I get here: no definite plot yet, but there's definitely one developing.


Moving forward, the story unfolds much like any other. First we're introduced to the grand stage: Midas, the Financial District, and Deals. We also see the consequences of Bankruptcy, and how one enters into the game to begin with. Then we're introduced to our main character, who of course enters into the game, and is thrown into this mad world of money and power with little to no clue as to what is happening. He is saved by his apparently experienced partner, called an Asset, who helps guide him through life in the Financial District. 


Not too bad, a couple cliches, but enough originality to keep things interesting. To be honest, cliches are actually okay to me. Just like tools in a toolbox, different plot elements are used to accomplish different tasks. When things go wrong is when inexperienced writers (much of today's manga writers, honestly) use the wrong element in the wrong place, making things seem awkward or forced. A good writer can take all cliches and make it feel natural to fit them together, or choose to use no cliches at all. Just like a mechanic picking and choosing which tools to use on a particular car, an experienced writer knows exactly when and where to place certain elements. And just like an experienced driver can take leisure with his driving style, choosing one or the other at will with little to no reason needed to do so, a good writer can quickly and naturally shift between different writing styles with no difficulty at all. C's writer is evidently good at what he does, since some of the cliches are self-evident when thinking about it, none of them jump out and interrupt the natural flow of the story.


As our friend finds his way through this new world, we get to see how he handles the changes to his daily life, as well as to himself. While I haven't seen how everything pans out yet, it's only natural to make some assumptions. So far from what I've seen though, I must give the story an 8. Why an 8, and not a 9 or a 10? Because while the writer is great and experienced, he fails to bring out some of the more interesting aspects of the story, and struggles at some points to develop the plot properly. However, it's my own impression that this is more a fault of the adaption process than anything else. Even turning a straight screenplay into a TV show requires sacrifices, though sometimes it's hard to tell the difference between honest mistakes and oversights.


Why an 8, and not a 6 or a 7? Because this anime does well one thing many others fail to: it takes advantage of its medium. This was also one of the notable features of Bakemonogatari, and one of the reasons that I liked that show. C uses its animation to explain a lot about the story that would have otherwise needed to be told in monologue. One thing that stood out to me in particular were the dialogues people had with their Assets, with the words to the left or right of the screen. While it added no new information, it was a nice touch that emphasized that these conversations were important to the viewer. Other such things were the usage of visuals to convey emotions. While this may better fall under the Animation category, I still believe it's important to the story to know how the characters feel. Also, many anime would have shouting matches, introspective arguments, or nervous breakdowns at this point, with the emotional characters spouting nonsense and generally being melodramatic. While good in some cases, this is obviously a side effect of the manga adaption process, where writers try not to throw out much dialogue and choose instead to sacrifice screen time in order to explain things that could've just as easily been explained in images.The fact that C, which I don't actually think was adapted, didn't fall into this trope (it's a common trope in anime, and even straight-to-anime stories fall into traps like these) really impressed me. Will there be such scenes further on? I don't know yet, and my rating might change depending on the outcome. For now, though, this is what I think.


Obviously a number of other things influenced my rating, but those were the major points.


[Art - 7]

This show uses a very interesting art style. It tries to blend together 3D and 2D seamlessly, but doesn't quite pull it off. It's not jarring by any means, so I don't believe it detracts from the enjoyment at all, but it's still noticeable. Ever play Borderlands? The 3D characters look kinda like that, while the 2D characters look like your standard anime companions. It's unusual, but again, it's not bad.


As for the drawn art, it's above average. The colors they use, the emphasis they place on certain character's features, and the backdrops all help to add to the atmosphere the show is trying to build. The line art isn't perfect, but continues to improve over the course of the series, hinting that it's a budget issue and not laziness on part of the studio. That, to me, is always the most important factor when rating art. If the studio is doing the best they can, I feel no reason to degrade them for the quality they produce. They're simply working with what they have, and usually it turns out good.


One thing I did notice, and the reason why I only rated a 7, is the 3D environments. At some times, it's good, seamlessly blended in with the 2D characters. At other times, it's pretty bad, obviously standing out and being a nuisance. The textures are the most noticeable problem: from a distance, they look fine, but up close, they blur unnaturally. Either they simply didn't take the time to make good textures, or they didn't bother to rent decent computers to do the rendering. However, I will note that the 3D quality increases dramatically during fight scenes, making them very pleasing to watch. This is a good plus for me, and while I wish they'd focused more on ambient scenery as well, it saves the rest of the show from looking too bad.


Aside from the 3D, the color palette they chose was beautiful. Stark, desaturated colors contrasted with bright, vibrant colors to create an amazing landscape inside the Financial District while the outside world is dark and gloomy, reflecting the overall atmosphere of the show.


As for the character emotions, as I mentioned before, they did a great job. Body language flows naturally, dialogue scenes actually have movement, and facial expressions do a good job of conveying what they are feeling.


All in all, the art is above average, and so I give it a 7.


[Sound - 8]

As with most shows, sound isn't something considered too important. Bad sound stands out and just makes things unenjoyable, but good sound is fairly easy to do so it's considered an expectation rather than a luxury. As for this show specifically, the sound quality was great. The wide range of noises and effects they used help contrast different scenes and convey the temperament of the characters. The background music was appropriate and the intro and outro songs - while something I don't typically pay attention to - were actually something other than J-Pop and enjoyable to listen to. They also did a good job of setting the mood for the series, which is always a plus.


All in all, they did a great job orchestrating this series, and so I must give them an 8. Why no 9? Because while good, the music and sound effects weren't outstanding, but they did exceed my expectations, and so they are above average.


[Character - 7]

The characters in this series don't seem to get much attention. Background and personal history are lightly touched upon just enough so that we can understand their motivations and personalities. In a way this is nice, as too much character development prevents the plot from developing if the plot doesn't center around characters, which it typically doesn't in an action show. Some characters have 2D motivations, but most have good - and multiple - reasons for the things they do, and the way they act. 


As for character interactions - something many reviews seem to gloss over in favor of talking about "Development" - the dialogues are quite natural and well written. Characters go into conversations with clear cut goals and reasons and no time is really wasted on nonsense. Some idle talk is heard here and there, but only enough to convey a sense of casualness in scenes where it's appropriate. The writer seems to remember a bit from General Education, as he makes good use of the RMO dialogue method, "Reason - Motivation - Outcome". As I've said before, it's more important to focus on the type of media being used rather than what the original story was supposed to be. RMO is for film and animation, and DDRAC ("Discuss, Decide, Review, Act, Casual") is for books and manga, which spare much more room for dialogue. The fact that the writer used the proper dialogue method is great, because it means we don't get entire episodes full of nothing but dialogue, or fight scenes where the characters don't actually fight but instead talk about their deepest darkest secrets and motivations.


For character development, we do see a good amount of it. While some characters are static (and they should be - some characters are simply meant to be staples for the main characters to work with) many - and especially the protagonist - do change over the course of the series. Some people confuse development with envelopment - that is, the difference between seeing a character develop, and learning about a character that's already developed or a character's past. We don't really see much history in this show, but we do see a lot of active development, which is really what we should be seeing.

Think about it: when was the last time you went through a chapter in your life, constantly talking and wallowing over the last chapter? If that's really how you handled it, it probably wasn't very exciting, and wouldn't have made for a great story. The point of a story is to tell of a person or group of peoples' journey through a particular period, not to reflect on what happened before that, unless it's naturally relevant to the story. So in that regard, the writer again did a great job.


[Enjoyment - 9]

My overall enjoyment for this series was high. While there isn't too much to analyze about enjoyment - it's purely a subjective experience - I can say it was mostly the story itself and the characters involved. Most of the characters were interesting and seemed real enough, despite their unusual circumstances. The story was well paced and the plot developed smoothly. Those two things interacted in such a great way that it managed to keep me captivated throughout each episode, and always left me wanting to see what happens next. The other factors - art and sound - while neither being outstanding - were good enough to provide a solid backbone for everything else to play out, which is what I think the developers wanted us to see.


[Overall - 8]

All in all, this is a great show. It's fairly abstract, intellectual, and not exactly groundbreaking, but still original enough to be considered new. It's dumbed down enough so that the masses can enjoy it too, and it's got its bright moments that really make you scratch your head and think. It's got a bit of philosophy, a bit of action, and a bit of conspiracy, and not too much of any one element. It emphasizes its strong points and does good to compensate for its weaknesses. The writer and studio both played their cards right with this one and it came out great.

What do you choose, the future, or the present?
*contains spoilers*
**very long and in depth review, so bear with me**
Guess i finally reached it - the point where i can review this anime with full understanding... And it only took me like what, 4 years to get the knowledge to be able to do so after my initial view of it? 
So yeah, as you understand, it isn't your average nut and takes some special tools (mainly proper understanding of economics, the worldwide economy model and Japanese economy in particular) to crack and get to the core.
So then since i mentioned that, its easier to startwith the negatives, since there are very few of them so it won't take long. First of all, i consider the fact that its so unavailable as a minus, since a person without the proper understanding of what i mentioned above will lose a lot of the meanings behind the actions, and some of what's going on. I consider it a slight minus since it takes away from the availability of the show, and the audience enjoyment and appreciation of it if watched unprepared. The other minus about it is that 3d graphics are often used, and sometimes make things look a tad awkward... Also there are a few things story wise that don't satisfy me since they go to waste and could be used to strengthen the symbolism and anime's message. And my final problem with the anime is the lack of the 12th episode (at the very least) that would allow to expand on the important scenes a little, and perhaps make the ending a tad more satisfying. 


Other than that, i think the anime is next to perfect. From the likable and colorful characters (especially the main assets), to the story, art and even sound, its all pretty brilliantly put together to immerse the viewer and not just for the fun of watching, but also as a word of warning and enlightenment on what is the world and its current state from an economical view point. Through the metaphors and the perhaps slightly exaggerated events, C points out the dangers of the world we live in as an economical unit (individual) and even as countries as a whole, using the magical influence of the alternate universe of the district on the real world to draw exaggerated pictures of economical catastrophes and their direct effect on individuals. 


***


The story mainly deals with two people, who in turn represent two different life styles and their matching economical strategies (oddly enough those could even be projected into politics and political approaches, but i won't go there since it will take too much time and will probably cause some flaming, but feel free to make the parallels yourself)... Note that none of the two is portrayed as the "right" one, as each has its pluses and minuses, and both of the characters are portrayed as heroic and positive.


First off - Mikuni Souichirou. Previously a rebellious rocker that quit that dream of his because he understood that he won't be able to sustain himself with that profession, leading to the breaking up of his band before a major contract was established. He moved to become the adviser for his father who owns a large company. His father puts the said company before everything, leading to unavoidable neglect of his son Mikuni and daughter Takako, and when an economical crisis strikes, he chooses his company over funding a low chance surgery in America for his daughter, leading to her death. This event is what forms, and finalizes Mikuni's personality.


Mikuni is understandibly furious over this, and after becoming a very successful Entré uses the money to buy out his father's company - the thing he cares about the most as a form of vengeance. Later, after noticing the effect Midas money is having on reality, he forms the Mukudori Guild that is directed to minimizing those harmful effects, and throws everything he has at that cause, hoping to help people in the here and now (which is the ideology he adopted after the death of Takako, for the obvious reason that she needed immediate help), even while disregarding their future and his own along with his very life (as seen in the end where he sacrifices fractions of his lifespan and eventually even his whole life to print money). 


His asset is resembling his sister and contains her soul (as seen in the end), and he is shown to care for her even as an asset, probably guessing, or feeling the truth at some level. She is shown to eat exclusively black Midas bills, further symbolizing the fact she needed money in the here and now to survive, no matter what the cost and origin of that money was, strengthening Mikuni's ideology. Since assets are said to represent an Entré's future, the fact she looks like Mikuni's sister Takako who is long dead, can be also taken as a hint that he has no future.


***


The second character and the protagonist is Yoga Kimimaro, an orphan that lost his father who was also an Entre to the financial district after he went bankrupt there and was probably forced to hang himself, or did so to protect his son from the effects of the district. The death of his mother isn't explained, but was probably linked to her husband going bankrupt in the financial district as well.


Kimimaro is a student at a financial university (and that somewhat ironic since the anime deals with economics, plus a little odd since his knowledge of economy is never brought up later, making it somewhat pointless to make that as his background), and works two part time jobs hurting his studies somewhat (some sources say he's a scholarship student, but i don't believe it since he barely can make ends meet even with the two jobs, and is shown to make nearly no personal expenses, to the point he can't allow himself to go out with friends, and is mostly forced eat cup Ramen).


Being an orphan and probably wanting nothing more than a family (having been raised by his aunt), he overworks himself and disregards his present (though that is not directly stated, but shown from his hard work and control of expenses), hoping for a stable job in the that will allow him to support his future self and family. After being lured in (and somewhat tricked) by a small sum of money and ending up as an Entré, he quickly shows promise and catches Mikuni's eye by defending his asset which is apparently a rare act that Mikuni himself was recorded doing before, and reminding him of his younger self later. He takes a liking to him, even to the point he plans to make him his heir in the future. 


At first, after witnessing and being shocked by the catastrophic consequences the financial district has on reality, Kimimaro accepts Mikuni's system of minimizing the impact on Midas money on reality and help protect people's present by joining his guild, however, soon the true meaning of Masakaki's (the jester like being that guides Entré's) words is witnessed - right in front of him, children (that represent the future, obviously) disappear off the street and other people instantly lose their future in the forms of their jobs and homes, even whole businesses and buildings vanish when a large sum of Midas money is printed in order to sustain the people in the here and now. It is at this point Kimimaro's personality is formed and finalized - he decides to protect the future instead of the present, leading to his duel with Mikuni. 


Kimimaro's asset is Mashyu, and since assets are said to represent an Entré's future, she is speculated to be his daughter but it is uncertain and somewhat awkward if it would really be the, given their slightly romantic relationship in the anime. Another speculation on my part is that she may be Kimimaro's unborn sister (since his father seemed to have had a similar asset, and bankruptcy in the district WAS shown to lead to make children disappear from existence, and that, again, may have been the reason his father hanged himself, to prevent his son from vanishing as well), although again, the romantic relationship makes it somewhat unlikely, but not impossible. The anime's ending also brings something sort of unusual to the table - a vision of japan without the yen (every price is in dollars since Kimimaro helped devalue the yen in order to destroy the local Midas money district that was based off of said yen, and bring, bargain, or buy everyone's futures back), what normally you'd think the Japanese pride would never allow to imagine...


Overall i think C is an excellent anime and a must watch for all those who have the required knowledge to process it, and maybe even those without it, since i did enjoy the anime on my first view even though i missed a lot of what is mentioned above.

C is a unique piece that blends together economics, philosophy, art, relationships, and everything else that makes up a person's life in an artistic way. 
Why I liked it:
- The story is original but if I had to describe it, it's like The Matrix, Vanilla Sky, Wall Street, Digimon, and The Matrix (again hehe) rolled into one series. It's a strange combination blend that somehow worked. 
- The music and art reminds me of the older Anime style, which was very nostalgic. The character designs are plain with the exception of Masakaki, the mysterious host of the Financial District. However, the setting of the FinancialDistrict had a very artistic feel that Salvador Dali would have felt comfortable in. \n\n
- Mikuni Souichirou and Yoga Kimmimaro had the most character development. Kimmimaro was always searching for an answer and a way. On the surface, he seemed like a lost boring character, but that's why he's a philosopher and why he was able to develop. Watching Kimmimaro and Mashu (his Asset) interact was entertaining. I also found myself paying close attention to Masakaki since he's the ticket into understanding what the Financial District really is.\n\n
- Despite not understanding how the battle system worked (I don't think the writers understood it either) and the other majority of things left unanswered, neglected, or misunderstood; in the end, it was enjoyable which is all that really matters.

C's story was pretty unique and original. The main character Kimimaro Yoga meets this (Willy Wonka like character)  and  is chosen to fight in a tournament ( or Deals)  which takes place in the " The Financial District." He gets his very own "Entree"(Guardians)  to fight in these tournaments. It appears that after the match- the losing person's loses his entire future !!!( it could be anything) While fighting in the tournament. Kiminmaro discovers that the real world is being affected each time they duel one another.   I love the fighting/ action i this anime and   usingmoney as power ups to aid their partner in battle : 0

Your enjoyment of this anime will depend on how far you are willing to suspend your own disbelief. As someone who would gladly escape the real world for anime, I thoroughly engaged with [i]C[/i]'s fictional economics. Now, if only real life were as simple as blowing up your rival entrepreneurs with giant laser beams.
Let me start with the fight scenes. They are sometimes too short, but always feature fluid and detailed animation. You will get your freaking laser beams of death. In addition, a good quantity of blood gets spurted, so make sure you're ready for some gory action. The main problem is, to reiterate,the fight scenes are too short. One fight scene even ends halfway, and the viewers never get to see the outcome. Way to skimp your fanbase!


Still, the art is decent. Not too extravagant or colorful, and a little bit shady.


The weakest point of this anime is probably character development. Kimimaro, the main character, has none of it. Mikuni, the main antagonist, has none either. Mashu, Kimimaro's fighting "asset", becomes a little bit more human, but not really. If these people weren't blasting themselves half to death with cute little girls, I wouldn't have been able to forgive such pathetically written characters.


Luckily, the overarching story makes up for character deficiencies. While simplistic, [i]C[/i] deals with the monetary debate between present and future. Should we give money to those who need in the present, or save up money for a better future? An interesting question to ask, and many of the entrepreneurs give different responses based on their experiences. And while they engage each other in deadly duels, their actions have negative consequences on the real world. You can't help but feel very sorry as the stories of those affected by greedy entrepreneurs are fleshed out in full detail. With both philosophical and emotional elements, the story of [i]C[/i] should be enough to satisfy most viewers.


Unfortunately, the ending sucks. Enjoy the anime!

Every season, I can always find an anime that fits into the "great everything, fail story" category. For the Spring 2011 season, it was this. 
STORY:
Nope, I don't think [C] was originally planned for more than 11 episodes and cut short eventually, just to let some of the supporters of the show know. The writers themselves should have known that anime in the noitaminA slots, for the past few years, have always been 11 episodes long (what a strange number). 
So what contributed to the subpar story quality of the series? Lack of proper planning. The writers were too ambitious and tried to incorporate toomany things into such a short span of time at once without thinking how are they going to write all of them out. And what do the audience receive at the end? A show with a magnificent setting but bad pacing. 


And I am not kidding here. The first few episodes were indeed good, the flow of the story was smooth and make you want to watch more and more. But came the infamous Episode 8, where one of the protagonist of the series suddenly turned to the evil side and the story was suddenly rushed. Most of the loose ends earlier in the series were not explained, a lot of time was devoted to the 'main plot' which started from that episode and left viewers with a big question mark on their heads at the end of Episode 11.


UNLESS, and I say unless, that the writers are planning to pull a Eden of the East on us and make a movie expansion to explain everything in this 'social commentary + Yu-Gi-Oh' series. I would probably forgive them for these loose ends then. But judging by the ending in Episode 11, it would be difficult to elaborate more on the story anymore.


ART:

Need I say anymore about this? Oh, I shall then.


[C] has probably the most fail story of all anime in 2011, but its art is probably the best of the year. Msyu's attacks, the skyscrapers of Tokyo, even every inch movement of the convenient shop colleague who our main protagonist works with, were animated with great effort. Not to mention the awesome CGI that keeps the battle scenes rolling on. It keeps me wondering how the hell did the sponsors come up with the animation budget...


...until the very end when I realized that they sacrificed the money from the screenwriter part for this. Lol.


SOUND:

Again, [C] shines at this. I particularly love those few soundtracks used during the battle scenes. Made the tension during the duels even more nerve-wracking. The OP and ED, not to brag, are really superb. 


Yay for Haruka Tomatsu as Msyu too. Her voice acting deserves a mention.


CHARACTER:

Throughout the whole series, the only characters who really had any development were Msyu and Kimimaro. Oh, you may argue that they are the main characters and deserved more development, but mark my words: devoting all the time for main characters and none for the supporting ones is normally not a very good idea. 


And it's proven. The other characters had so much potential to be great characters, but were shoved away at the very end. Soichirou, for instance, was doing nothing until Episode 7, when we finally see a bit of his backstory, and at Episode 8, when he had a bit of development at least. But that only lasted for 3 episodes. The blonde chick was another fail example. She was also doing nothing until Episode 10. Heck, need I mention my favorite character Masakaki? He could have made such a good antagonist!


OVERALL:

I won't force you not to watch the series if you want to watch it, but for me, [C] is an anime that I would probably recommend it to those who were only watching it for the art and the music. Let's hope that the writers would know better what to do next time when they are planning a new anime series.

The anime shows us one ancient truth - even if there is a destiny or a pre-made future scenario we control the outcome with our actions (in other words we still have a choice) and if more people depend on us the stronger we are, yet if we fail the people that trust us fail. That could lead to a disaster, by the time the main characters understood this it was almost too late. The anime was depressing for me but it reminded me about the heavy price we must pay for our decisions. My advice - next time you make a decision think aboutit carefully, you must not  live for the moment, tomorrow may be your last day or it may be not it depend on your decisions that's what the anime had in mind.

C the Money of Soul and Possibility Control tried to deliver an interesting story that combines both realistic and fictional elements within it. That be said, the creators did, in fact, accomplish what they had set to achieve.
Story (9/10)
The biggest factor that helped this anime is the story. Now, how many anime do we see that revolve around financial matters that could destroy the world? Not many. The story has a solid background and a defined structure. However, some elements were left out of the plot line, although they are implied (How exactly is Mashyu the main character's future? A suggestion as to what shemeans/will be is implied). Overall, the creators were able to create a good solid plot line for them to build up.


Art (8/10)


The art was decent enough for viewers to enjoy. I personally did not care much for the 3D designs the creators added from time to time. In fact, sometimes it deemed confusing for the viewers. However, the artwork itself is crisp clean and enjoyable. The opening was nothing special, although it did represent the nations of the world within it.


Sound (8/10)


Good background music, but nothing special or out of the ordinary. The opening theme was catchy, but, again, not that special.


Character (7/10)


When it comes to characters, C the money of Soul and Possibility Control has a range of different characters that fulfill their needs. However, yet again, some unanswered questions are left. Who created C? What about Masakaki? These are left for the viewers to deduce.

The characters could have been developed in a more realistic manner. The main characters had potential, and it was fulfilled in the last episode, though unanswered questions, as I mentioned, were left behind.


Enjoyment (7/10)


Whether you know anything about finance and economy or none at all, C will deliver an enjoyable show for viewers to watch. Intense moments combined with beautiful artwork and sound will make it a decent show to watch.


Overall (7/10)


I was not expecting a masterpiece out of C, but it did deliver a solid story that is both realistic yet fictional at the same time. The different characters and plot line all bring out a certain element that stays within the viewer, even after finishing the show.

While still watching this anime I was tempted to give it a 10 just because other people have rated it so poorly. 
Now I know I am right to give it a 10.
The first episode wasn't too convincing, I wasn't too sure what was happening. Ep 1 is also the reason why I rate the art with 9. The backgrounds look nice and I've nothing to complain about those but the characters really needed more details. They look like they are cut-out from some other anime. Or they just don't blend in. other than that, they are okay and look quite pleasant.
I'm not going tomake a summary since I consider MyAnimeList already did that, I'm just gonna give some reasons to watch it.


The idea is absolutely original and personally I enjoyed it a lot: the whole series is a metaphor for the market and economy; the market is a battleground, the rich people always win while the poor struggle for their lives.. In this case, the battleground is the Financial District, a sort of parallel reality to the real world, where the Entrepreneurs (our characters) fight against each other, helped by their Assets (cute fairies with superpowers). Theor money, future and present life is at stake. This is why I think they done a great job setting motivation for the characters in this anime. I mean we've seen a lot of war/military/SF series where people just fight against each other just because they are "enemies", they take sides, they hate each other. Well in [C] things aren't really like that, while in appearance they fight just for money and they don't really die, if they lose, depending on the amount they lost in battle, things do happen in their real lives. They are driven in duels because of greed. And I guess that is a very nice parallel between FInancial District and real world: greedy people get blinded, risk everything and lose. They sell their soul basically and the need to make more and more money enslaves them to a system that they can't afford to let go of.


I suppose not all age ranges can be entertained by such a theme as money and economy. You do need to take your time watching this and try to see behind scenes. The characters don't really develop but that is not really necessary here: I think the idea still is that of a metaphor, every character represents something. 


Regarding this, I have to say that this time, picking an average ollege student as main character is not really a cliche, it's simply the best choice there is if you want to picture the situation: he doesn't yet have a future, he needs to pick a side, to decide what he wants to do further in life. He has to be the aggressive one because he must find his path. 


Everything is related.The relation between Kimimaro and Msyu reflects upon what the asset actually has to be to an entrepreneur: taking care of your resources is the best way to fight your way to the top. Financial District is the place where is better to be safe than sorry. Every character, in this respect, has its own way of fighting and I think that is great: I've never actually seen different fighting strategies developed for characters depending on their pattern anywhere else. It's a good action anime but if you don't take the time to read behind the lines I guess this is not for you.

Have you ever asked yourself "Hm,why should I watch this anime?" "How is it different from other one?"  "Might it be only a waste of time?".Of course you have,I'm just making an introduction here for an already empty review.
Story:Great (9/10)
I loved it.Usually when someone says "Unique story" it's just a simple compliment,but this is literally a unique story.Using money as a battle system,and seeing the impact of a fictional world in the real world made a good combination of action and story development.Sadly,first episodes reality just passed as a backup story,but meh,you can't ask for everything.
Art:Good (7/10)
I don't know,It's not bad,but being from 2011should make it have a better quality in my opinion.


Sound:Very Good (8/10)


Opposite from Art,Sound is notably off.You could say it's not something to complain because it's not even there,but when you notice there is background music it's not the beeeeest.

That aside,I loved NICO touches the wall's opening and Tomatsu (Asuna) voicing Msyu,so maybe that is why I gave it an 8


Character:Great (9/10)


While some people complain about character development (Aside from Msyu and Yoga's relationship,which I think got a bit rushed at the start) I think every character was great enough to fit in the anime with It's own story.I mean,I don't like when a new protagonist appears from nowhere and starts doing it's things,neither when 2 episodes are dedicated as a new character intro.Neither I feel that would be bad,but hey,what do I know?


Enjoyment:Great (9/10)


Overall:Great (9/10)


Great story,Great characters,Great ending and a must-see anime as the product.

WARNING: This review is going to be really boring. "Why?," you ask. Because [C] is really boring, and it's boring to talk about. I can get excited over a good thing because I can find creative ways to express my like for it. I can get excited over a bad thing because I can think of different ways to tell it to eat the ass-end of a north-bound cow. However I can't get excited over [C] because of how fucking boring it is. You have been warned, so don't complain about that if you're going to.
[C] is about a kid named Yoga, who gets transportedto an alternate dimension after accepting a mysterious cash fund in his bank account. In this alternate dimension, he has to fight different people in order to secure his future, which the dimension has as collateral. Every other fighter there does so as well, making this a fight to secure Japan's future as a whole. Each victory or loss has an adverse effect in the real world. As he battles, it becomes apparent that all is not what it seems to Yoga, and different people have different ideas about how to manipulate this dimension to affect theirs.


My main problem with this story is that it's not original at all. What it is is a Frankenstiened mess of other anime; most notably Death Note, Serial Experiments Lain, and Soul Eater. From Death Note, we a get a moral dilemma tailored in a similar fashion, only handled so poorly that we don't know entirely what it's asking until the very end of the series. From Lain, we get an alternate dimension that controls the real world, only less awesome because the impact left on the real world is known from the start and the way they raise the stakes at the end is laughable at best. From Soul Eater, we get a fighting system with someone at your side that's humanoid but not actually human that acts as your weapon, but less cool each battle is boring and predictable. The staff even know that because one of the battles cuts off in the middle of it and they declared Yoga the winner because they couldn't think of a way for Yoga to predictably win it. Aside from making the aspect that they stole from each anime pathetic, the idea that these three anime can mix together is not a solid one. I can see someone connecting Death Note and Lain, but adding Soul Eater into the mix is just ludicrous. These three anime are so different from each other it doesn't make sense to mix them all up; But, if you're determined to do so, don't string them onto a boring plot that thinks it's better than it actually is.


The main story is one that's been done before and better. An under dog-type character finds himself in an odd situation and begins to rise through the ranks, which is seen by the characters in it as shocking and which isn't seen by me, because I dosed off five minutes in. That is the entire extent of the plot, except when it tries to be deep. I say "tries" because each "deep situation" is bland as hell and something people could see coming from miles away. Most of it talks about about how this dimension is affecting the real world, and when I say "talks" I mean "drones on pointlessly, while alienating the audience." I know Darker than Black did something similar, but the universe in that set up in is in some way interesting and has a colorful cast of characters, which links me neatly to my next point.


The characters are somewhat of a paradox. They're incredibly bland and uninteresting, but to the degree where they're so bland they're unforgettable. Yoga is the under dog hero of the anime, who stumbles around the series, trying to decide which moral side to take. His fighting partner is Mysu. Her role consists of bitching to Yoga and harboring a secret crush on him. The main villain is Mikuni, not that they want you to know that. The series tries to hide that fact very clumsily. His fighting partner is Q, a stoic character that hardly talks, probably in fear that whatever she says has to come from the same snooze-worthy script that everyone else's dialogue comes from. Other characters include a pessimistic teacher, a secret agent girl, an information broker with gold teeth, and a few others I can describe in whole using simple terminology. The only two interesting characters are Masakaki, who works for the alternate dimension, looks like the nephew of The Count from Gankutsuou, and consistently has fun in his own little way, and Sennoza, a rich charity worker, who's incredibly strong and tries to make the script more interesting. Seriously, the rest of the characters sound like their actors knew this was going to be boring going in and didn't even bother (I watched it subbed, by the way). These characters as a whole though are just as bland as the plot, except Mysu who is annoying as hell, and I would sooner leap from The Eiffel Tower than consider her likeable in any way shape or form.


As for the art, it's bland as well. For the alternate dimension, it looks like they tried to fix the artwork of Gankutsuou and fucked it up. At least Gankutsuou's art look interesting in some way and had some feeling behind it. The art here looks like it was made by a robot programed to make something interesting without any reference material at all. The real world artwork also looks boring, but without any specific thing to rip off of, so it looks like that robot's programing was set to "generic." Still, the artwork here is just boring and not smug, like the story, or annoying, like the characters.


The music is also generic as hell. Uninteresting in every way. Even the opening theme, which is by Nico Touches the Walls, the group that did the second opening for FMA: Brotherhood, which was an awesome song. What happened here? Did you guys agree to make a generic song for the anime, or did you look at the anime and make a song to match? My money's on the latter. Still, there is one saving grace for the music, the end theme. It's bye the same people that did the end theme for Eden of the East, another great theme, and this group decided to take the Sennoza route and tried to make the series interesting. As it stand though, the music is the least bland part of the series only because of that.


I'm sorry that I've been repeating myself, calling [C] boring, bland, generic, uninteresting and such. It's just that there's no other way to describe the series. However, if I talk about the end, that might give me some wiggle room in my vocabulary. So, Spoiler Alert here. If you don't wish to be spoiled, just skip to the end.


The Death Note styled moral dilemma centers around the choice of living for today or living to live again tomorrow. This is an interesting concept, but it doesn't come up until very late in the series, as I've mentioned before. It doesn't get addressed until the fate of Japan is at stake, which is a sloppy way to raise the stakes, which I've also mentioned before. The last few episodes of [C] have plot points that fly past faster than a caffeine addict in a race car and are never explained, and things begin to happen for no reason. Or maybe there is a reason, I just didn't pay attention to the boring dialogue long enough to make it coherent. This is all in effort to make [C] look tough and edgy enough to play with the big boys in the anime crowd. A hopeless effort I might add, because it makes it look incredibly silly and not serious at all. The ending of [C] is rather bullshit. It resets itself so that it leaves off where it began, and no effort has been made to offer some form of closure. I guess that was a little more interesting, but not by much. It was worth trying anyway.


Overall: [C] is just an extremely boring anime with less substance than an empty jar. It thinks too highly of itself and is unoriginal in almost every way. It's not a bad anime though, just very inorganic. Something that you could make by putting a bunch of better anime into a blender and mix in some sludge. Don't watch it, unless you are suffering from insomnia is basically what I'm saying. 4/10

[C] is one of those series where it probably could have been amazing if it was longer; with, let’s say, 24-26 episodes, [C] could have really turned out as an awesome series. However, the 11 episode limit here is what really limits the potential for this anime as a whole, where there simply wasn’t enough time to fully explore the characters and setting. The results of this lack of time was a poorly executed pacing and a lot of dangling plot lines that have yet to be resolved.
The main thing that really catches your attention towards the beginning is the setting. The creators placed atremendous focus on the mysterious Financial District, and did a great job at building and fleshing out the setting. There was a sense of exoticness to the setting, with the rules and regulations to the battles and such rather intriguing at times.


However, this explicit focus on the setting pulled away a lot of screentime from the characters, leaving behind a cast of characters that are really bland and difficult to sympathize with. Seriously, Kimimaro remained a passive onlooker until the very end, Jennifer got little to no development until the last two episodes of the series, any mentioning of Kimimaro’s father just disappeared, and Souichiro’s mentioning of the conflict between different factions in the district (starlight guild vs whatever) completely vanished into thin air. The only real character worth noting here is Mikuni Souichiro, and even he ended up not doing anything exceptional for this series.


In the end, [C] was a series that was just too outright ambitious. It had a lot, and a lot, of interesting ideas and a well built setting. However, the serious lack of time in being able to flesh out these aspects to the show is what caused this series to falter.

This review is for individuals who are planning to watch this anime a.k.a. SPOILER FREE!
Let's first begin with the storyline. C is an anime that is unique in its own nature due to its complex storyline in addition to its abstract concepts. A simple viewing of the 1st episode will indefinitely pique one's interest due to the authentic interactions between unknown characters. In retrospect, this anime is definitely unique with its abnormal storyline; by creating a world that is unlike any other anime, this thriller definitely piqued my interest. 
In contrast, many viewers will find the first couple (1-3) episodes confusing, and I will admit,I was confused myself. It is completely up to you to decide whether you want to invest your time learning about this complex system or simply drop the anime. My recommendation is to suck it up and watch the god damn show, because every anime is essentially unique, and it takes time for someone to get used to its character. Since C is so abstract and authentic, it WILL take a while for you to get used to it, but once you are comfortable with the storyline, everything becomes a beautiful art of work. Overall, the storyline IS INDEED confusing, but only because it is so unique and different when compared to other works that it REQUIRES you to take time and understand everything. Story: 9/10


When looking at art and sound, all I can say is that these two elements are profoundly emphasized. The fight scenes are exquisitely drawn in detail, while the entire show is highlighted with majestic artwork. When looking towards sound, I am not that big of an observer, but I did not find major flaws regarding voice acting/ sound effects, so I'll give both these elements a 10/10.


The characters in my opinion are overall great, but not perfect. I find that the show leads you to assumptions that you really shouldn't even be thinking about. I'm not going to spoil anything so I will leave you to decide what I am referring to. However, I will admit that the character development is genuine and graceful. As you progress through the show, you will find emotions changing, mindsets shifting and even notice your own heart swaying. The time invested in character development in C is limited due to its requirement of helping the viewer understand fundamental concepts of the show, but the subtle shifts in the personalities of the characters are clearly evident, and the outcome of this evolution is sincerely beautiful. Characters: 9/10


Did I enjoy this? HELL YEAH.HARAMBE! Truly, given the tag of 'thriller', if I did not feel hyped or wanting another episode, then this anime obviously failed. I sincerely enjoyed the episodes, sometimes leaving me at cliffhangers that made me envy more. Although I will admit that there are certain aspects of the show that leave me bored or confused, as I finished the entire anime in a span of 2 days, I felt relieved that I didn't waste my time watching a worthless show. In all honesty, I found this anime truly wonderful. 


Overall 9.5/10

(A 9 wouldn't be enough to highlight my enjoyment but a 10 is a bit high...9.5 it is!) I hope all you guys enjoy this anime as much as I did. Thanks for reading :)!

As an undergraduate studying economics, I knew that I have to give this show a shot. I would skip the main summary, since you can easily read the synopsis. This review will basically help you to decide if you should watch this anime. 
Story 7/10: A refreshing story that serves to differentiate itself from the rest of your overused cliche story line. Deciding that it should try to stimulate the average viewer with some economics, finance and values. It too manages to cater itself to both the mature and younger viewers with its well executed story-telling that highlights the darker side of our capitalist societythrough the story's economic recession. Despite the well executed story-telling, the main story line was only introduced nearing the last few episodes, making the whole journey choppy, rushed. The lack of explanations for the sudden twists also didnt help its viewers to understand better.


Art 9/10: Well drawn, realistic scenes of Tokyo and Singapore. some CGI, 3D modeling. Definitely no complains.


Character 6/10: Although several characters were introduced, their thoughts and emotions were not fully explored other than the MC and his antagonist, Definitely a lot more could be done with its fantastic story telling to explore "the girl" and other characters.


Overall + Enjoyment 7/10: The story's refreshing settings and art, with its wonderful OP and voice acting makes the whole ride pretty enjoyable, despite the fact that the story felt a bit rush, making you feel that there the writers have missed out something. Fight scenes were mediocre, but the fantastic art makes up for it. In conclusion, it was an anime that did not realize its potential.


Watch it if you:

- Wants to be intellectually stimulated

- Wants an awesome OP, good voice actor, and realistic scenes of Tokyo

- Looking for an anime that has a seinen feel to it


You shouldnt

-Wants awesome kickass OP MC that is the chosen one + actions

-Cant stand episodes where they explore the characters' histories and thoughts for 10mins.

-Everything within the story must make sense to you.

- Cant stand depressing animes.

Slade’s Quick Review
Almost no one knows about this hidden gem of an anime. But now you do, cause you found this review! I often feel a lot of different anime are not for everyone. However, this show is for everyone because its for no one. Now you may think that sentence a bit contradicting because it is, but this show had nothing about its main plot that sounded interesting to me. An anime that revolves around currency and has strong economic impacts that effect the story. Though in the end I think this is one of the best anime ever! Just ignore the summery ofthe anime because it doesn’t matter you have no idea what kind of trip you are about to go on watching this show. I do feel its plot is a bit better for a more mature viewer but a younger viewer can still watch and enjoy the show just the same. The only gripe about the show I have is near the end it gives me a headache trying to understand what exactly was happening since I don't have a degree in Macro or micro economy. This anime just caught me off guard, and I am not going to lie but I really enjoyed this anime. The concept/plot of this anime is very intriguing and it makes you keep on thinking that if you were is a situation likes this then what would you do? 
For e.g. I think most of the people here must have had some time in their life where they were short on money and that moment in life is the worst, you can’t do nothing and if you don’t have someone close (family/friends/relatives) to help/comfort you then that becomes one of the most miserable moment inone’s life 


Well moving on this anime is without a dought a must watch series, this anime just depicts that money can literally turn the world we live in upside down and more the money one has the more influential and powerful that person becomes. There is also another thing that I want to mention is that that pacing of the anime is done exceptionally well, when I first read it’s plot synopsises I thought it’s quite hard to believe that such a complex plot was fit within 11 episodes, so they might have skipped a lot of things and yeah they did skipped some fights however it didn’t affect the overall plot.


There are two things that i really liked about this anime, first being the music (it really fits the mood and is quite good) and the second being character development yeah, this one was the most important thing for me because we actually god to see the evolution of Yoga, Kimimaro , and that’s it if you haven’t watched the series then please go and watch immediately because it is truly amazing, Thanks You

Personal mini review:
I went into [C] not expecting much, and coming out with another anime in my top 10list. This anime is original and smart, I enjoyed every episode of it's short series, the main 5 or so characters are very memorable, however the supporting characters do not leave much of a footprint in the sand. This series deals with adult and understandable themes such as an individuals present moment and their future, love and the changing of the world before someone's eyes. The character relationships grow in a fantastic way which leads to you not wanting the series to end. The pacing of the show is pretty bad however, it feels like they were shoving too much Into each episode, I believe it could have been even better if they stretched the series over more episodes or made some of the less interesting (still interesting just not as interesting as the main) story lines shorter.\n\n
This series definitely deserves a season two or light novel expansion, it is under rated and deserves more praise than it has received. \n\n
*minor spoilers*\n
The ending is fairly open ending leaving you too choose your own ending, there are two highly discussed ones, and there is relevant evidence for both, I'm not sure if this was done on purpose to allow for both parties to enjoy the ending or whether neither of them fit the writers ending at all and the ending is what it is.
