Don't say pass!
Okay. C is actually not the best anime out there enough to motivate me to write my first review, seeing as I gave it a 6, but it did. I feel like I wanted to defend it or rather give my side as to why it should be given a chance.
The plot of the story starts off with an interesting premise, not so unique but it showed potential. However, it is not the story line that damaged the show--it is actually quite consistent with the facts--the problem for me is it lacked depth. It was too fast-paced that it didn't give emphasis onsome matters that could've helped supplement the viewer's understanding of the story. There were a lot of times I had to pause and ask "how did he come to that?" then recall previous scenes in my head to fully grasp the situation. I did get to understand it because, again, all the facts you need to comprehend the story is there.


The art's not the best there is but I actually like it. How the financial district was drawn reminded me of Gankutsuo, but to those who tend to look at the symmetry of the drawing, especially the eyes, might find it disappointing.


The sound was okay for me. Not so memorable.


Because the story lacked depth, it affected the characters. It was confusing how Kimimaro learned to use direct. Wished there was more fighting to show that Kimimaro actually got better enough to stand up to Mikuni. The pace of the story also affected the connection of the viewer's to the character. One of the best way to see whether a character is successful or not is when they were able to elicit empathy from the audience. In most scenes, it just didn't for me.


Even if I gave it a 6, I did learn a few from this show. It's philosophical so it might target your values. It's refreshing to look back at yourself sometimes to check what you put on weight more. If you did not understand where the story is going I suggest you to re-watch it.


Again, it's not the story in itself that's the problem, it's the depth--but everything is in there for comprehension. I wouldn't say that the story is rushed, it's more like they tried to fit in everything on those 11 episodes. But do try to give this series a chance. I'd still recommend it.

SPOILERS BELOW: PLEASE DO NOT READ IF YOU HAVEN'T FINISHED THIS SERIES!
Alright so I'll say this right away: my argument will most likely be biased because of my love for this series (but then again who isn't biased to some extent).  I've seen quite a few people post about how [C:] tried and failed to upkeep things they created, tie in Economics properly, ect.  Personally, I feel that if you think these things that there is either a reason or you're not looking hard enough.
[C:] is very much about Economics.  I'll try to keep the symbolism explanations simple:
Midas Money = Loans
The reasonfor this is because Midas Money gives you purchasing power in exchange for your future.  Ultimately, that's what a loan does.  When you take out a loan, you enter a legal contract saying that you will receive temporary money in exchange for the thing you spend it on (since the money you spend using the loan isn't really your money, it's the banks).  Ex.) You take out a loan on your car.  If you fail to repay that loan, the bank will then own your car.  In [C:]'s case, they are trying to invest in their futures.  If they can't pay back the loan (the Midas Money) then they lose their future as part of the contract.  When people go bankrupt within the Financial District, they have lost all their Midas Money, and can't pay back the loan.  The future that they invested in (whatever it may be, for the teacher it was his children and wife) will be taken as compensation.


The Financial District = The Capitalistic Economy 

Before the Industrial Revolution, there were not many "businesses" so to speak.  For the most part it was part of what you grew up in, and it was what you lived on for basic needs.  However, after the Revolution, the topic of Business became very appealing and profitable, but to start a business you need money.  In our modern day economy, most entrepreneurs start up their businesses on loans (in [C:]'s case - Midas Money).  The life blood of most businesses are formed and thrive off the loans that they obtain.  The Financial District is a representation of this new economic structure.  New Entres borrow Midas Money to start up then fight in  "deals" to basically take the money of the person they're fighting.  Note how ALL the money in the Financial District is Midas Money.  That's because what they are doing is fighting with the financial power form their loans to take the financial power of other Entre's loans.  It's somewhat odd, and it's why it's questioned in the series if the Financial District is good or evil.  After all, business keeps the world going and goes towards the future, but the entire Financial District uses money that really doesn't even exist (loans - Midas Money)  


Assets = Entre's Future

The assets of a business really are the potential future of the business.  They are the entirety of power, so to speak, the business has.  If a business loses all it's assets, the business has no future, it is dead.  In [C:], the assets can be "invested" in.  Likewise, in reality, you can invest in your own assets to hopefully gain some type of progression (such as technological advances) to improve your assets ability.  In [C:], that "ability" is portrayed as supernatural abilities to win deals.


Masakaki = Personification of the Will of the Economy

I know Masakaki isn't a term, but he does represent something.  The economy isn't something that can be fully managed, controlled, understood, ect.  Masakaki shows this time and time again by refusing an offer that would seem logical (such as when Yoga tries to buy back his teacher's future), appearing at random intervals (surprising people), giving Yoga a "Black Card", ect.  Although, Masakaki didn't necessarily GIVE the Black Card.  The "one from above" did, the laws of the economy did.  Masakaki is simply a servant of this "economic god".


Now, I'm off the terms, and I'm onto complaints that I've heard before:


"The mystery of the Financial District is never solved" - It was never meant to be solved.  The viewers are called to see the connection between the economy of the modern day and the Financial District.  Even though you see mythological guesses at what it could be in the series, you should see that they're meant to be only as such, guesses.


"What's with the Deus Ex Machina at the end with Yoga and the Black Card?" - The ending isn't supposed to be displayed as the main character using his "main character powers" to somehow beat the odds or to gain something to beat the odds.  Like I said previously, The "one from above" that Masakaki refers to is the law of the economy.  The economy is volatile and unpredictable so when Yoga gains the Black Card, it was because it's sending a sort of message that "you can never be too sure".  I know it may sound odd, but when this scene occured, I realized and recreated on my own face, the smile that Masakaki is always seen with.  The idea that the economy is just a game.  Now, I understand that the economy isn't purely chance nor is it purely a game, but it does have those aspects to it.


"Some of these asset attacks don't make sense at all.  They don't fit in with what's happening."  - The asset attacks aren't supposed to "work" with their actual physical form and context.  They are meant to just perform a "move" that sounds like what it's name could be used for.  Mashyu used fire-type attacks so they found a few economic terms that could be used with fire (Scorched Earth and Overheated Economy).  The argument could be made that these moves represent the asset's personality, goal, ect. and through them the entre's personality, goal, ect.(due to the asset being the entre's future).  For example, Mashyu's Macroflation is Overheated Economy.  An Overheated Economy is caused by huge amounts of spending and leads to inflation.  To reduce spending, loans are sometimes reduced in availability.  This means less people can borrow money, and less amounts of money can be borrowed.  The Financial District runs on loans (Midas Money) so Yoga and Mashyu could represent the enemy of the Financial District in that sense as well.


subcategory: "How is Q's cannibalization and economic term?" - A simple search for economic terms with cannibalization in it can solve this problem.  The one that seems to be the one Q is using is called "Market Cannibalization" which is when someone produces a product that ends up harming the entire market.  


"What's all the random stuff with the Future and the Present?  It doesn't relate to the economy at all." - The main thing is the use of Midas Money (loans)  it's a philosophical  battle to determine if loans are something that should exist or not, how the economy should be operated, and the reasons why.  My friend compared this battle to the arguments between Kaynes and Hayek who are very intelligent economic philosophers who had very opposing views.  Kaynes being played as Mikuni, and Hayek played as Yoga.  Even more than the Future-Present battle, Mikuni believed that having a ton of money to influence the economy is what should be done while Yoga just wants to live an average life involving no forcing the economy to steer in the way you want.(also opposing views with Kaynes and Hayek)  Mikuni wanted to completely hold the Financial District.  By preventing deals and businesses competing, there would be no reason to invest since you don't need to compete.  You're all in one giant business so to speak.  Because no investments are made, the future isn't being aimed towards.  There will be no future advances because of no investments thus leading to a present standstill - only caring for the present and consumption now instead of later.


There are more complaints, but none that I can think of immediately.  Finally, I just have some side-notes of [C:]:


Whenever the world "changes", it represents the business going bankrupt just like in our economy, but in [C:], these changes are not only instant, they never existed in the first place.  For example, let's say that in real life there's a shoe store and it goes out of business.  In a few days/weeks, the spot/building where it once was will be replaced by a new business; in this case let's say it's a shirt store.  People will remember the shoe store, and the shoe store employees will have lost their jobs.  In [C:], the shoe store immediately becomes the shirt store, the shoe store never existed, the employees of the shoe store did something other than working at the shoe store (possibly being jobless during the entire time), and no one notices the change.  This aspect of [C:] really is meant to be an eyeopener to the horrors of bankruptcy, and also, near the end of the series, the horrors of a recession. 


To further explain my point about the entre's losing their future, I want to use Ko (the angelic charity guy) as an example.  He was funding a charity program for many poor children.  Once he went bankrupt, his money never existed.  He never spent it on the charity, and all the lives that he saved were never saved in the first place.  The future that he invested in with the Midas Money was taken from him because he couldn't pay back that loan.  The same goes for Yoga's teacher who lost his wife and children.  


All in all, I loved this series.  It's my number one anime tied with Mahou Shoujo Madoka Magica.  This series has a hell of a lot of connections through symbolism which is very admirable.  Simply put: the creators didn't half-ass this work.

I decided to watch this anime because the screenshots reminded me a bit of a toned down Count of Monte Cristo and I am still on my quest to find animes with adult leading characters. I figured, why not? It's about a college student with a major in Economics who gets wrapped up a battle to prevent the economic collapse of his country...sounds pretty interesting. Well this is no Wall Street. 
It's basically about a guy named Yoga Kimimaro who looks like a highschool boy but is supposed to be in college...I suppose I can overlook that as not everyone looks like an adult incollege. He majors in economics yet knows next to nothing about money, investing, and so on. He basically just works at a convenience store and save up. He's in love with his friend who has a boyfriend and the story begins when he gets a random deposit of a large sum of money and a visit by a weird being from some other realm they call the financial district. Now I'm going to stop it here and go over what we have so far.


Yoga is by far the most milk toast, boring, passive b*tch character I've seen in quite a while. I wonder if anyone has to come into his bathroom and wipe his a** for him case he's too passive to do it himself. We get a glimpse into how passive he is when he never speaks up to confess his feelings for his friend. you would think that this would be a flaw he would have to resolve in the end, and he sort of does...sort of but we'll get to that later. During most of this anime this guy just walks around as everyone explains the plot and he's so freaking ignorant when it comes to the economy to the point where you wonder why he's even an economics major. By the way he looks and his ignorance, you might as well say he's a highschool kid. but I guess even the creators realized how stupid it would be for a high school kid to participate in a financial game and save Japan from economic collapse. So they instead created this “might as well be a highschool kid” character with the title of college student and economics major.


So let’s continue. He gets taken to another realm…because it would be boring this was a slice of life about people dealing with Japan’s tough economy and there he has to pay a money battle royale type of game that is never fully explained because the creators know nothing about economics except a bunch of keywords. While there Yoga draws the attention of the main bad guy with a sister complex and daddy issues, Souichirou who is the boss controlling everything there. They do a good job of setting up this character and his personal goals. So much so to the point where I wonder if they should have just made him the main character. He’s an adult, more involved with economics, more knowledgeable about the financial district and its effects on the real world economy (although not smart enough to realize that pumping the economy full of money is not good), not perfect, not passive, has a more defined past, and the list goes on. But I guess that would make too much sense. Instead he’s the exposition guy. He stands around informing the main character of everything for some odd reason because the main character attracted his attention…still trying to figure out how considering the fact that the main character is about as interesting as watching paint dry. 


Then we have another exposition character…because the plot is so far gone to the point where they needed multiple characters to explain what is going on. I forgot her name but she just walks around talking about her investigations and eating burgers cause that’s her quirk. These characters basically have to explain the economy and so on to this so called economics major as he battles people with money powers and supernatural creatures. Smh.


Overall, I liked the art style. It was sort of monte cristo like which is cool and well, at least the characters were all adults even if one is questionable. The ending was what I expected it to be. Rushed, convoluted, and “explained” by a third party. Oh and if your wondering if the main character stops being such a  passive b*tch. Well, he acknowledges that it’s one of his issues and he tries to resolve it by standing up for his beliefs…after he’s told what they should be. The plot with the girl he had a crush on was dropped so there is no resolution there. Then he’s told that his choice at the end was for nothing so, so much for making decisions for yourself that other people say you should make. Lol!

I watched this last night and while I enjoyed the story itself there were a few issues. The 3d wasn't very well integrated, and was often jarring when a 3d model is used for a character on screen with a 2d character (it looked very MMD) and there should have been double the episodes, there were many plot points that were introduced that are never expanded upon. I would say over all that it is a good anime, but I will say that the ending is a little melancholy if you think about it too much.

After watching some anime series i noticed that most of them are losing their's original concept after 20/50/200 episodes.
And i really don't like this inconsistency.
But in [C:]'s case i'm feeling like it's original concept was dropped after 5/6'th! episode. 
Still, it is a great show, with nice music, beautiful art style and great characters.
Unfortunately, ending somehow ruined whole point of watching it.
Why? 
It's incomplete.I presume that this show was meant to have more seasons and in it's current state ending is a bit depressing.
But continuation will probably never happen, DVD sales were low.
Still it's one of better shows aired in 2011 and it's worth givinga shot.\n
And who knows? Maybe they will release another season after a couple of years.

This is a series that I still maintain could have definitely been expanded into something much, much longer and would have been all the better for it. "C", for me, is the promise of what could have been, the anime has some fantastic bones and a really great, really interesting concept which could have really been a sturdy foundation for at least a second season, though I think the more they could have elaborated on it and explored it all, the better. "C" was an anime I had no idea of going in and I was blown away by how much I enjoyed it, it'sdefinitely an anime I'll always be fond of even if I think that 1) the "romance" moments are so forced and awkward they border on self-aware, 2) the few moments of fan service are not needed and break the tension, and 3) the entire thing was wrapped up way, way too quickly. Maybe I'm weird and a little too analytical for my own good, but I would have loved this anime to have been as long as possible and really delve into all of the aspects, the characters, and the plot lines which a series focused around economics could explore. The idea of an economics anime doesn't sound like something that would be as good as it was, but, while I'm very sad that it was never really given a chance, "C" is an anime I'll always cherish as one of the biggest surprises I've gotten in my experience with the media, it really shocked me how good it was, how much sense it all made within its own world, and how brilliant and genius the whole thing was. Whoever came up with this needs to do more work because they are brilliant, but, now, I guess all I can do is fantasize about all the places that this anime could have taken me. :)

When I first heard of this show, I thought to myself, “Is this going to be a show about the economy? If it is, where could they possibly go with this concept. I would imagine that this would be a very boring show.” I was right about the economy part, but this was certainly not a boring show. The synopsis and title already had me interested in the show, but I wasn’t in the right mood to watch.
It was only when I was in the mood to watch something different from the rest of the shitty anime that I was watching at the time iswhen I thought of this show. While I was watching the 1st episode, I was confused but curious about what this was all about. Ever since that realization, there’s no going back.


There will be spoilers for episode 1 (b/c it’s the 1st damn episode) and nothing else.


Anyways, I hope this review helps…in some way.



Story: 8


This show is “Money makes the world go ‘round” personified, combined with a card game aspect. Counterfeit money (or Midas Money) can only be seen by the people that are associated with the Financial District, a place that can only be accessed by individuals that have a reason to make money and desires to make more of it. Our main character runs contrast to most of the people in the Financial District in which he doesn’t want to make a lot of money, he wants to have a normal job, have a normal family, and live a normal life. 


Masakaki take him to the Financial District and introduces him to the idea of Deals. In short, it’s a wager match in the form of a 1v1 fight (as in an actual fight). He also gives the MC an asset, which is used in Deals. Assets are a manifestation of that person’s future, so the MC’s Asset takes the form of a young girl that can actually speak unlike the majority of the other Assets shown in this show. He explains that losing a Deal in the Financial District causes you to a part of your future, even worst if you go bankrupt in a deal.


When it comes to the story of this show, I think it’s great story that centers around the economy and shows us how the Financial District can impact the real world. The main problem of this show is not the story itself; it’s the lack of sufficient world building for the Financial District. There is some world-building for the Financial District, but there wasn’t enough for a show like this. Masakaki is the character that has the most knowledge about the District. He mentions a hierarchy in the District, but doesn’t say anything about who they are, what they do, and possibly what they’re thinking. He also stated that the Financial District has always existed alongside the world and only really came into play when people developed economies. If that first part of that explanation wasn’t there, then this would be more interesting than it already is. The whole explanation of “existed since time began” or something like that, I think is a very cheap way to explain either a character of an alternate dimension.


Overall, this show has a great story going for it, but it suffers from a lack of sufficient world building that could possibly expand on the story and the characters. There’re also minimal plot-holes and no retcons in this show as well. 



Art/Animation: 8


Initially, the art was incredibly sub-par, the 2D animation felt stilted and expressionless, the CGI animation was stiff as hell, and the 2D/3D animation moments were incredibly clashing; it made the show look bad. After around Episode 5/6, many issues I had with the animation were gone and the show increased in quality with each episode (barring a few scenes that looked like utter shit). The fight scene in the last episode was fantastic with great choreography, pacing and progression with a constant back and forth struggle between the two characters. It honestly was a sight to behold, wasn’t really expecting a scene like this within the show.



Sound: 9


The OP is a nice track done by NICO Touches the Walls, but after around episode 5 or 6, it doesn’t fit the show at all and I started to skip it at that point. The ED on the other hand reminded me of several tracks that came afterward like Liar Mask and V.I.P (I can’t be the only one that hears that right?). Not only are the visuals from the ED different from many others, it also thematically fits the show and the song as well; one of my favorite EDs of all time. It’s too bad that the full version of this is so hard to find.



Besides those 2 tracks, most of the tunes played can sound weird at times, but it matches the nature of the Financial District. Some of the other tracks are mostly forgettable, though they are mostly used for atmosphere, so I won’t complain about it too much.



Characters: 7


Msyu (Mashu): She’s Kimimaro’s asset who initially started off as a typical asset that has close to 0 character. As the show progresses, she ironically becomes more human, in more ways than one, than her master. It’s quite funny. I do find it weird that she got the most character development out of all the characters in this show. Even Kimimaro got less development than her and he’s the MC. 


Yoga, Kimimaro: He was a normal college student other than the fact that he’s pretty much broke and works 2 jobs. Since the beginning, he was set on living a normal life, earning money normally, and raising a normal family. After his encounter with Souichirou, his actual character appears off. At times, he’s decisive (especially when it comes to Mashu); other times, he’s passive and can’t decide. By the end of the show, he’s finally figured out what future he wants for himself and everybody else, but I won’t spoil that, just watch and see.


Mikuni, Souichirou: This person was a complete mystery in the beginning of the show with his ideas counter that of the protagonist’s, making Kimimaro wonder for about half of the show if the normal life is what he truly wants. Souichirou got the most backstory of all the characters in this show, and it’s actually interesting to see how that one event changed his entire life and idea of a perfect world. (I feel really bad for him)


Masakaki: When he first shows up in front of Kimimaro, he gives off an unsettling vibe (but that CGI/2D animation scene doesn’t help this at all) that make you want to avoid him at all cost. After introducing him to the concept and rules of the Financial District, he takes a backseat in favor of the other characters, which is a shame because he has the potential to be the most interesting character of the show, if not one of the most interesting characters of all time. Sometimes he changes things around, claiming that it was “orders from his superiors”. It’s too bad we really don’t get to see those characters.


Most of the other characters aren’t worth mentioning. Granted, there are a few characters outside of these 4 that are important to the story, but I won’t spoil who they are or what they do.



Enjoyment: 9


I really don’t have much to say here. I really enjoyed this show for what it tried to do, and I think it executed those ideas well. Story was really good, Art/Animation was sub-par in the first 5 episodes and jumped in quality as the show progressed, OST and Voice acting was great, and the characters weren’t the greatest but a good amount of them got development and backstory.


I loved the concept of the Financial District and the contrasting ideals of Present vs. Future. I like the unique visuals that are shown in the District and ED; very creative and different from everything I’ve ever seen.


Overall: 8


The reason why most these are 8s is because these concepts weren’t utilized to their fullest potential (reminds me of DBGT in a way). Story would’ve been higher, but the insufficient world building hindered it. Art/Animation, as mention earlier, was sub-par in the first 5 episodes. Not only that, there are multiple scenes early on that use both 2D/CGI in the same scene, which is very distracting. Episode 6 and onward don’t do that as much and the 2D and CGI animation improved significantly, but that improvement happens in the second half of the show. 


Although the OST is mostly atmospheric, it genuinely enhances the current situation in some form, with the ED being the best track in the whole show. The characters are the weakest part of the show, mainly because not enough of them are given enough backstory, development, or their motives aren’t revealed. The ones that got development and/or backstory are either important to the story or they’re side characters that will be relevant sometimes.



I fully recommend this show to people that want to watch something different.

Fun to watch. Events in the district that cause changes in the real world are implemented brilliantly. I like how they show the assets speaking to their owners. The idea of Midas money, demonic printing press, future and the economy is interesting and fairly unique combination. I don't recall seeing an anime like this before. I liked the art and animation, assets and the district were colorful and diverse. The assets were cool as well, representing each persons future differently and having different attacks and abilities. Fights scenes were well done and interesting. The one thing lacking was the relationship development of real word people(the people at college) with Yoga. Although, they may have wanted to focus on him and Mysu, which they did do quite a bit. The end seemed to just cut off when more could have been done to show, say, how Mysu was his future. It is only hinted at what she is in the story.

I loved this anime, it has a very sophisticated story although they often used terms related to accountancy like "assets" and many more. 
The opening theme and the ending theme are not bad as well.
Besides the fact that it has a good story the art was great as well, I also loved the fighting scenes even though they fight for money (first few episodes) but it turned out to be fighting for your future. 
I was satisfied with the ending even though its a sad ending.
This anime became one of the best anime that I've watched so my overall score is 10.
I recommend this animefor people who love anime with action, and a bit of romance.\n\n

(Excuse me, as this is my first review. I couldn't resist after watching this.)
I'm not sure about the low reviews, but I can say one thing for sure. This anime is one of the best I've seen.
First off, the art and story. It's both pure and original. The story is something unlike anything I've seen. It's true that I only watched it due to it being recommended from Eden of the East, but even this is a completely different turn from that. You have a generated currency which is pretty much endless, if used right. You have to fight in Deals to gain more moneyand to stay in the world. If you go Bankrupt, you're kicked out of the world and all your money is taken from you. From the point of another person, it would seem plain. It's far from that, very far from plain. It's the essence of a masterpiece.\n\n
The soundtrack was something that I picked up on right after the first episode. It brings the mood to the anime. It strikes it at the right time. It's beautifully made and one of the best I've heard. As for the OP and ED, they're both great. Now, for the background noises and such, they're accurate according to anything else. The voices fit within the duels and act funny if enough is spent. It seems to make sense.\n\n
Overall, a stunning 10/10. This is a must watch for an anime enthusiast. You're missing out on a great thing if you don't watch this.

A very intelligent anime that uses action and excitement to almost educate the watcher to how a part of the world works. Even if your not interested in the more serious themes involved and enjoy a nice combat anime this one i still recommend.
The character interactions were one of the more interesting things about this anime. Its as if all friends are enemy's and all enemy's are friends. as weird as that may sound it's the kind of feel they give you. Then watching those relationships evolve and progress is rather exciting.
The series manages to pack a lot of story into just  a smallanime season, left me wanting more and hoped for a 2nd season to come along one day. With some unresolved plot points that weren't entirely fundamental to the progression of the story i could see it one day happening.


I highly recommend this intelligent and exciting look at the world economy.

There was a lot of hype surrounding this work because of director Kenji Nakamura, who made a name for himself with Trapeze. Having seen Trapeze and remembering how good it looked, I was really expecting a lot. However, blurry visuals and legendary QUARITY made me genuinely disappointed in it. Story wise, it does some things that have never been done, and for that, I commend it. But its finanical discussion never really steps beyond Econ 101 level, the characters aren't particularly engaging, and as gg fansubs so eloquently puts it, the main premise ends up being primarily "Yu-Gi-Oh with credit cards". When it does stepup, though, it really STEPS UP, and it's almost worth watching just for the awesome last few episodes. Other than that, though, the series was, to me, consistenly mediocre.\n
Even so, the series' constant Engrish is pretty fun to randomly quote to your friends, and you'll find yourself constantly wanting to shout "YOU HAVE GAIN" in public places. Quite embarrassing. Recommended for fans of Yu-Gi-Oh and Pokemon because of how the bullshit battle system works. XD

C
I had high hopes for this anime; it had a good original story line, beautiful characters and lovely art. However this managed to disappoint me towards the end, and let me tell you why. As it good closer towards the end it felt really rushed and many things were left unexplained also some characters were introduced for one minute then gone the next without real development also they were apparently important to the plot. Furthermore I noticed in some bits of the anime the art style changed at some bits of the anime which made me wonder to what were the animators were doing atthe time when they designed the scene. 


Although there were many good aspects to the anime such as the main characters developments and the story line. They were wonderful and these were the reasons that kept me going in the anime also I believed if they were given more episodes and time (which could be easily done as they have enough material for it) this would've turned into one of the best anime of the season. 


Overall this anime is not the must see anime but I believe it should be watched at some point, as a guilty pleasure. Although the ending was a bit rushed but I believe it was the only time limit that was given to the animators at the time.

C: Control - The Money and Soul of Possibility follows Kimimaro a young boy after the loss of his parents he wants to have a normal future, making just enough money to support a family. A simple and normal life till one day a mysterious man comes to his door named, Masakaki he helps maintain the
financial district where people fight for money with collateral of there future. Throughout this series you watch as Kimimaro struggles to keep the present the same and to look forward for the future while all these horrible changes are happening with the financial district. So Kimimaro is required to fightto save the worlds future. Personally I loved this series it just wasn't quite a 10 but really close to it. I found there were minor things I didn't like the short amount of episodes only at 11 and the way they ended it off they could have done more but it was also great ether way. I love the artwork in this anime series it was just beautiful with amazing story and characters to back it up this series really grips you in from the first episode.\n

C: The Money of Soul and Possibility Control had an interesting premise and pretty good OP. However, almost everything else was executed poorly. Since I completely wasted my time with this show hoping that it would be fulfilling, i'm angry enough to write an review on it. 
Note: I do have a potential spoiler rant at the end of the review.
Story: 3
These guys had absolutely no idea what they were doing when it came to the plot. 
The setting and the idea was great, hell have a gazillion dollars and fight other people with money? COOL! However, the writers didn't seem to know what todo after they came up with that super cool idea. It had a reasonably slow start, an unreasonably slower middle, suddenly OH LOOK "-----C------" is HAPPENING EVERYONE PANIC. Don't even get me started on that asspull at the end, that was bullshit and you know it was.


 In between the time Yoga came to the district and the time -----"---------C---------"--- absolutely jack shit happened other than introducing a shit ton of characters (i will get to THEM in a second) and deal after deal. No, we did not need a character breakdown on a teacher that we didn't even recognize until it was pointed out that he was a  teacher. No, we did not need to stretch out activities for the guild and watch as bland characters go "hahaha we're so cool". NO, WE DID NOT NEED AN ENTIRE FLASHBACK ABOUT A CHARACTER WHO ALREADY TOLD HIS STORY TO THE MAIN CHARACTER EPISODES AGO. 


Instead of wasting their time with pointless and unconvincing  character introductions and development, they could have wasted their time enriching the world and the system that the writers created. Rather than spending episode after episode explaining the effects on the outside world, lets talk about the district? Questions and facts that should have been answered at the beginning of the series still remain unanswered even after the series ends. I could go on, but i'll just make it simple for you:


You go in with nothing and leave with an awkward end, more questions ( if you still even care about this shit story), and maybe a conscious to pick up a penny whenever you see it. That's it. 


Art: 4


The background and scenery was good. As i said before, i liked the world and setting and i loved the nice art that came with it. However, the level of QUALITY in Psycho Pass episode 18 was the same level as every single episode of this series. I had to pause at some points of the show because i could not fucking believe my eyes when i saw the blatant CGI flop this show presented. Seriously, what the fuck? At least TRY to stay consistent. See, if Mysu was 3D-ified only inside her card world thing, that would be okay. But after I saw Yoga go full 3D model walking down the street i was pretty much done.


Sound: 8


ISSOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO KOWASHITE KURE YOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO


matryoshka etc etc 


The OP is one of the best out there. At this time, i'm listening to it constantly. The OST gets you pumped, and at the same time its fun. No voices were irritating to listen to, except for maybe that Caribbean guy, and yeah, they did a great job with that.


Character: 4


There are only two characters that will catch your interest in this show. Mikuni and Mysu. Yoga at first seems like a promising protagonist but ends up becoming bland and annoying, like everyone else, a few episodes later. I guess the writers just decided to focus on other things because they were just done with him at a certain point. 


There is nothing remarkable about the white hair girl other than the fact that she bought three fast food cheeseburgers at once and only ate one. Oh, and she goes "OH MY GOD RAAAAUGH you can use my pokemon HAHAH YEAH YOU CAN DO THAT YOU GUYS COOL RIGHT?/!!!!11" 


None of members in the guild were interesting. Maybe it was because there was no proper character introductions for them or...? Their literal purpose was to Make Mikuni look like a super cool badass businessman.


Mikuni was interesting, and yes he ended up as my favorite. The writers knew that Mikuni was going to be popular so they basically spent their entire budget on him, giving him a pointless flashback, making him in almost every single episodes when he really wasn't needed, giving the little character development they were willing to give to him, making one of the two characters with a solid personality. 


Personally, I thought Mysu was annoying at first, but she is a character that you warm up too as an asset learning about human stuff. If you are going to watch this at any point even after reading this review, watch it for her.



Enjoyment: 6


Yeah, i gave it a decent score because  i enjoyed the deal battles. There were also times when i was 'excited' and hoping that something cool would happen. Especially with the cliffhanger bullshit they pulled, and then you sat through the opening? Super cool.


Overall: 4


The show had its good points. I sat down and watched it and hell I thought it was going to be a strong success. However it just ended up being a blatant laughable disaster. So yeah, don't waste your time with this show.



(Potential spoilers below)


And the end, oh my fuck the end. Where did the black card come from? Why the hell didn't we know that Yoga had this fucking card at the beginning of the show? Where the fuck did this card come from? What are the qualifications of getting this card? Plot? There is no way in hell this DARKNESS card does anything but just make money, and the fact that they made the card only have that certain role and present it out of nowhere is appalling. There is a difference between the element of surprise and pulling something out of your ass.


(Potential spoilers above)

Alright, this will be my first review ever, so I'm sorry if it seems tacky etc...
I just finished watching this anime and I want to give out my opinion on it.
First of all the goodies:
- Music / Sound world overall
- Epic battles
- Summons (that kinda remind me of Persona and such!)
- Story idea
Negatives
- Characters
- Too little episodes (maybe the pacing too at times.)
So let's go through these things okay?
First of all the music and sound world in this anime is GREAT. I'm not saying the music is exactly memorable to me, but it still fitted the situations at hand in the anime. Especially at theend it gives you a nice, soothing feeling. The sound effects are point on and nothing seems "out of place." The voice actors are fittings as well, though when they were speaking in English, it wasn't as high quality - but that's just my personal opinion.\n\n
The battles!! I really love them! They really remind me of Persona with the whole card summoning idea. Except this time they are based on your money. They keep you entertained, though sometimes they appear to be a bit too short. I guess it brings in some realism in sense, that no one is able to keep going forever at it, but I was expecting there to be...MORE... into them.\n\n
The story is original as well (or well I haven't bumped into similar kind.) The whole idea of how money makes the world go around is a very nice idea. Even in the real world money brings you power and this anime just goes to show you that, with some fantasy elements added in, of course.\n\n
On to the negatives now.\n\n
The story seemed kinda rushed considering it was filled in with only 11 episodes. I really would've hoped there would've been a second season, because this anime would've worked that way A LOT more. They don't really give you time to get to know these people, besides maybe the main character - and even his past is in a haze for the most part. They just kept kicking in more random characters to the show and expecting you to just suck them in and not care about them. Which, btw, happened. I didn't really care for many of the characters, except the ones that were in the main light. I would've loved to hear more about Masakaki, for example. What he is, where he comes from and such, but it remained as a big mystery. Maybe that was the point of it, but it kept bothering me how I never got the time to get to know these characters. \n\n
All in all it was a great show and I enjoyed watching it. I will rate it 9/10 because I found more positive than negative about it. It might be a bit of a loose rating, but once again, this is just my opinion :) I hope you will give this show a chance! It starts off kinda EHHHH, but ends up being really epic! And 11 episodes isn't a lot, so it's easy to go through in couple of days (if not even in a day if you're crazy enough.)

You know the story background, its on ANN. I'll just write my thoughts.
Story: Surprisingly good. Good in the sense that its very unique. I liked how they attempted to keep a balance of economics and shounen. It would be better if it was 24 episodes, since the ending was sort of abrupt and left a few plotholes. Moreover, it loses points on using a motif used over and over again (I'll spoil it if I say it).
Art: Not bad. But the CG got very noticeable at a handfull of points, which bugs me. Also the animation wasn't very fluid (Thank you PA Works for makingmy standards very high now).


Sound: Another outstanding soundtrack, as expected from Taku Iwasaki (gurren lagann, soul eater). Opening and ending were amazing too. VA was pretty decent too. Also A-A-A-A-A-A-ANGEL.


Character: Liked how it was a poor college boy and not some angsty teenager. But I feel the development for the protagonist was a bit rushed. Also forced drama.


Actually, you know what, just get the OST and forget about the anime. You won't be missing out on much anyways.

"C" gives us an in depth viewing of how the power of money can influence our future. I personally thought the very concept behind "C" was fresh and skillfully written. It was a very plot driven anime which managed to fit a very action packed well developed story into an 11 episode series. In fact, I would say "C" seemed to "flow" as if it were one long movie. 
Although it could had been more refined in some areas the story was on point for the most part; and any plot holes were easily dismissed. For those who need an explanation for every little detail,I'd say explanations were not necessary for this particular anime.


The colors used were vibrant. The character models themselves however were standard although this is not really a detriment.


The opening and closing theme songs were good, although not great. I was more interested in the BGM which featured a cello and other string based instruments. 


Again, for being an 11 episode anime the main characters were well developed. Their reasons for participating in battle were clear and logical. The characters themselves were likable and although slightly archetype this doesn't take away from the  overall plot freshness.


This was a well developed anime with the potential for a second season although I don't think there will be one. Overall "C" deserves a solid 8 for its originality and intrigue. Other review sites have rated this anime as only "good" but I feel it deserves better.

I read some reviews a bit harsh to this anime, but they tend to follow what I think is a wrong trend , trying to be too brainy into what is to be entertainment...and this series is really entertaining.
Springing forth from a rather dreary theme, and setting it with an intriguing fantasy reality and with interesting characters, every episode is very enjoyable, and the main protagonists all are interesting and well performed. 
Art is unique and makes use of good coloring, adding a real nice overall visual feel to the story.
Sound and music are really good as well.
I do think they could have gone deeperwith Mashiru and her Entrer, but the concepts and ideas are original enough and the story is well handled, if rushed in the end, therefore my 7 to overall rating.\n\n
I do think some reviewers are way too harsh and sometimes fail to simply enjoy a really entertaining and well handled anime...trying to see too much where simple enjoyment is enough.\n\n
Well, those are my ideas anyway....and I do recommend C...
good anime but ending was not the best but still good noe the less but i have seen alot of anime like it but for a 2011 one it look relly good but some plot holes in the story

Good anime with an original concept and which shows an actual problem that can't be resolved even now: Money.
Art: 9
Not original in creation of Assets but in rest everything is good.
Character: 8
 A classic concept of a newbie defeating a veteran. It doesn't show any variations or deviations from this concept.
Enjoyement: 7
 I think that modern anime MUST focus more on action rather then drama. Also in the old anime(Slayers, Yu Yu Hakusho and others) they succefully combine the drama with action. However the modern creators doesn't know how to do that and as a result the anime ends with an OVA or something similar

The title I think is misleading in a sense that it doesn't talk much about economics. Instead it explores certain theories on what is more important for society such as what is more important: The numbers on the computer screen or obvious effects you see among the people. 
In addition, the anime is focus on battles between certain users of a "society" alongside their assets in a form of some battle stead. If they lose, the lose part of their future as a collateral. This go again with the misleading title since it was not about strategies for an economy, but more like battles tomake economic decisions. It did not mean I did not enjoy it since there was some sort of character development, decent story line and a little bit of anxiousness on what is going to happen.\n\n
I really wish they came up with a better title, but then again its probably was hard considering what the story was about. A decent watch.

Yoga Kimimaro gets roped into the Financial District, a world which makes the saying “money is power” literal. Entrepreneurs (or Entres for short) fight one another with their Assets (partners) in weekly duels called Deals. Each Entre's future is held as collateral. So with each loss, their life becomes worse.
It reminded me of Accel World, except that this was a parallel world instead of a game world and that this show is centered around money. They did well by making economics look less boring and turning it into a decent action/super power show. However, I felt that it was too short and quite rushed nearthe end. They had also yet to explain quite a lot of things, such as exactly how a defeated Entre’s life will be determined.


Overall, a decent show with a cool concept but lacking in content and might have been better if it was longer.

This is a rather unique anime, and easily falls into something that I've said for years, you can make anything interseting if done well.   This is a anime about economy and money disguised as a monster fighting anime.  
It's best going into it without knowing too much beyond that, but I found it enjoyable, and the strange twists, and how I would say things parallel and work as alagories for real life is facinating.
Each of the main chars I liked though wish some had a bit more screen time, this is definetly one that could have maybe been helped by a fewmore episodes.  The visuals and little changes and things that happen as the story progresses work very well.   Give it a shot if your looking for a action anime, but done differently.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS (a little farther down) 
MAL always tells me to 'Try your very best to not write any spoilers.' I'm just going to go ahead and IGNORE that suggestion. This review will cover why I like and highly recommend this anime, but to do that I will have to clarify many things. In fact. It would probably be safest to say that this review should be read post-posthumously, so to speak. After you finish the anime. Which you should. Immediately. 
To begin with I want to say, as many other people have, that this story is unique. Not original, that hardly canexist any more, but unique. It is an extremely creative mix of stuff we've seen a dozen times over. Normal human gets given crazy powerful cute helper. Has to fight in duels (usually against their will), ends up saving the world, etc etc. However what it does so well is take what has been done before, and provide it another setting. It's like saying a painting of a flower by Van Gogh isn't unique or original because it's a painting of a flower. Don't be ridiculous! It's taking something familiar, and doing something different and beautiful with it. I honestly think that's the best way to describe the general feeling of this anime. 


I guess that summarises my liking of the art, sound and story mostly, but let me continue :D 

Story : 8 - It did have flaws in some areas, and for those neat-freaks out there like me who struggle with a story that (I would argue intentionally) doesn't answer every question, the ending is a little difficult to stomach. (Though I think it was a beautiful ending. We over-complicate things so much sometimes.) I won't make much comment on the whole 'money' 'future' thing because honestly I don't think it's a huge issue. If you're willing to not be nit-picky, I think it's quite easy to grasp what the producers were going for and they used an interesting medium (the economy) to do so. 

Art : 9 - I usually quite dislike this art style, I'm no artist so I can't say what style it is or why particularly, but I loved it in this anime. It had moments of subtle colour and romantic drawing, and it had moments of pure raw bursts of two or three raging colours that clashed and warred and portrayed emotions of confusion, fear, pain, very well. Q, anyone? :P


One thing I'll say in this section, because there's nowhere better to put it, was how extremely CLEVER the producers where in using imagery. There were times in this anime that a character would be having a monologue, but the imagery that accompanied it (like the ants and the wasps and the frog) were another creative means of telling the same message. And that's just one example! The way each scene was structured and the amount of imagery stuffed into each episode was REALLY impressive. Not to mention those crazy cool backgrounds.


Sound : 9 - (skipping sound, though I really did enjoy it. a lot. I'm just not much of a musician nor do I pay a lot of attention to it. The fact I noticed the soundtrack at points, even actively turning it up during some of the later episodes, is praise enough.)


Character : 8 - Solid characters. Enjoyed them all, large cast so some suffer, obviously, let's not dump the expectations of a 100 episode show onto an 11 episoder. Seriously guys, appreciate what you're given. If anyone actually understood the conflict between the two main protagonists, you should get this reference :P One main thing is that with any show this short, each character (even some major ones) Is essentially just a tool to fill a certain plot roll. Aside from the three main ones, Mysa, Yoga and Mikuni, pretty much every other character did in this show, so naturally it may feel as if the characters aren't developed fully. Of course there's missing potential, but they did what they were needed to do, and they did it well. The plot progressed extremely smoothly thanks to the extremely good, in my opinion believable, characters. The white haired lady was a good example of this. 


NOW SPOILER TIME


Back to story, though I prefer the term 'plot'. 


I read through a discussion feed after finishing this anime, and most of the comments were either voicing a lot of confusion, or annoyance. 'but this didn't happen' and 'but why'd this character do this' and 'who was that crazy character they showed at the end' etc etc. 


I always find it extremely frustrating that people are so willing to slam a show simply because they weren't paying attention enough, or smart enough (trigger warning) to get a more-complicated-than-average-plot. It's the same reason shows like Darker than Black (albeit that never finished, which caused much of the confusion) is often only loved or despised. Some people seemed willing to invest the time to understand all THAT CAN BE UNDERSTOOD, and willing to simply roll with what CAN'T be, and that's extremely important!!! As a completely novice author, I can even say that as the author, you can sure as hell bet I don't have all the answers, but they aren't necessary to what I'm trying to say or do. To much info would just clutter an otherwise interesting story, and I promise you there are animes like that out there. 


The same is true of C: One on of the criticism I read was (SPOILER) about who Q was and how she realised that she was Mikuni's sister. She never died people! In episode seven, during the telling of Mikuni's story, it pretty much ends with these word's "With that Takakoa lost consciousness, and has not awoken to this day." Comas are a thing you know. So of course she's still in his future, there's no reincarnation going on or any shite like that. Hell even that's a misunderstanding, the show repeatedly emphasises that Assets are 'representations' of the future. the title of the show is 'possibilities'. Assets are not realities! That's why, for example, Mysa is a representation of Yoga's future, because she is named after his dead little sister (presumably what his father lost when he went bankrupt, and also the reason why his father committed suicide, just like Yoga's professor was going to do. The information is all there! It's just not shoved down our throats so every moron can understand!! (thank god for that) It even has a seen where Yoga, as a child, names his little sister (the spelling was slightly different Misha, I think, but the pronunciation was exactly the same. 


I could go on but I feel these examples make my point. Don't criticise this show because you don't understand it, first, consider that it's complicated, quite philosophical, and short. Then, if you can't piece it together, go back and re-watch it! I'm not saying everyone has to like it, but don't write it off because you don't understand it. 


If you've never heard normal classical music before, a lot of it will sound like gibberish because you have no comprehension of how they wrote different movements into their music, all the technical skill that goes into writing it, the effort that goes into playing it. Just because you can't understand or meet somethings standards, doesn't mean they're bad standards. 


Sorry for crazy rant. Hope you all enjoy. And if you're annoyed at the spoilers, I think I gave fair enough warning.

C: The Money of Soul and Possibility Control is going to abbreviated to C: for the sake of my fragile keyboard.
[Story~9] Alright the story of C: is great, but it doesn't make that much sense without a basic understanding of finance and a high attention span.
[Art~10] The art is very good among one the better art-styles I have seen recently, but art is mostly in the eyes of the beholder so watch it and form your own opinions.
[Sound~9] Great sound effects and coordinating, I mean how bad do you have to beto get this wrong?


[Character~10] I feel like this category is mostly up to personal option, but for what is worth all the characters in this anime were well developed in my opinion.


[Enjoyment~10] This is one those anime's that make you feel empty after it is finished because 

A: It is a original so you can't read the source material 

B: It has a ending but it is incomplete (Like Angel Beats ending)


 Overall I enjoyed this anime, but after finishing it I automatically know that I must start on a happy anime with a happy ending in order not to start spiraling into depression.

This is a review on C: The Money of Soul and Possiblity Control which I think is a very underrated anime for the message that this presents. Without spoiling much, this anime shows us how money can affect our lives and how we come to view money today. In this anime, a chosen group of people are able to gain enormous amounts of money by putting their futures as collateral and fight with "Assests" which are a representation of one's future.
Story: 9/10
     This anime has an original story that deals with how money is represented in society and what money reallyis. The pace of this anime reminded me of the well known "Madoka Magica" as clues to what was really happening in the Financial Distric and the scheme of the Starling Guild started to slowly unravel episode by episode. The story of the anime really opens one's eyes to how money can affect one's future if they are not careful and what money really is. The story is very enjoyable although budding romance between the main protaganist and his asset feels very rushed and unncessary. Besides the romance, I truly enjoyed this anime and greatly recommend it.


Art: 8/10

     The animation was quite well done and similar to many of the recent anime series that have aired. The fight scenes are pretty flashy and enjoyable as assests duel and the background reminded me of the background in "Black Rock Shooter". The animation also feels very smooth, but nothing spectacular that we havent' seen in recent anime. The art really doesnt take you out of the story, but isnt anything new.


Sound: 8/10

      The sound was appropriate for the story with eerie and suspenseful sound in the background. It fits quite well with the scene that is presented and the transition between sounds during scenes are very well done as it smoothly transitions from a fight scene to a new discovery. I think that the sound and voice acting was done pretty well overall.


Character: 8/10

      The characters are pretty well done except for a few exceptions. Most of the characters are relatable especially when they reveal their motives later on in the anime. The character development of the main character and his assest as the story progresses was well done as the growth of the characters are pretty clear. You can see the slow growth of the main character as he begins to realize the value of money and what it really is. The other main characters are also relatable as their motives are slowly shown through the anime. My only complaint with the characters are that the side characters really didn't feel important and were just placed there to further the plot with not much development or motives.


Enjoyment: 9/10

      I really enjoyed this anime and got the same feel as when I watched "Madoka Magica". I was really sucked into the themes that it presented and changed my perspective of how money works in our society and how important it is. I truly recommend this anime to anyone as it is worth the 4 hours it takes to watch it.


Overall: 9/10

      Is money worth your future? How much can your future change even if you are careless with your money just a little? What can you do with money? What is the true value of money? Is money really powerful or is it just powerful because we choose to believe it is? How much influence does money have on our future? These are all questions that are raised and answered as you watch the anime. This really opens your eyes to how money is viewed in society and I highly recommend this anime to anyone who will be dealing with money in the future.


This is the end of my review for C: The Money of Soul and Possiblity Control. I hope you enjoyed reading this review (even though it was super long) and I hope that you will take my advise and choose to dedicate 4 hours to watching this amazing anime.

Story: The plot and setting are not entirely new, combining the battle royale concept (most similar would be the Accel World I'd say) with another anime's premise of having "infinite money to fix the world", Eden of the East. That said the characters do face the problems/consequences that would come in such a given world and grapple with them realistically (grittier fashion would be an apt way to describe it). However due to the short nature of the show (11 episodes), the story gets a bit incoherent towards the end and viewers may want more (It does wrap up but feels very abrupt).
Art: The animationis good. Although the use of CG may be a bit weird at first (wasn't expecting it), it blends together well. The fight scenes are pretty good (with the exception of one that's just skipped over, you'll know when you see it), although there's some stereotypical shounen moments where despite the battle raging around the characters feel the need to talk.


Sound: Individual tracks were not particularly stand out but musical choices during the scenes always fit. The opening/ending tracks are great and were the reason I got more interested in the show.


Characters: The characters weren't exactly spectacular and ran into some tropes (most notably the MC being indecisive when given sudden power). However they are believable and understandable, with enough in the short episodes to give you an understanding of their perspective and motivations. 


Overall: C definitely had more potential and would have benefited from a few more episodes, especially towards the end. However the short time frame was use well and  also removed the excess that a lot other animes usually have (characters repeating cheesy lines and filler). It asked the questions expected of its premise and answers them with few "twists" or plot points that stand out. Solid viewing experience.

Before I start I would like to say that this is my first review as I am new to mal so forgive me if I'm a little off topic or not sure on what to start. 
I for one enjoy sci-fi animes. So when I heard of this one I just had to watch it! After watching the first few episodes I was a little skeptical but once it explained the whole idea of what's happening I started getting hooked on it. Not only that but the sound for the intro was great! Such visuals and catchy music just made me so into the seriesI was hoping for a second season! I enjoyed the way the animation is and the plot behind it was pretty rare. It's not something you would normally see in a anime storyline. But overall I would recommend this show to fellow sci-fi/romantic watchers out there. But if you don't like it at least it wasn't a complete waste of time. It's only 11 episodes!

Initially, I had quite low expectations for C after reading the premise, but I was assured by a friend that it would surprise me in a pleasant way. He was right. C has several unique aspects, but I wouldn't call the work prolific by any means.
Story: Kimimaro is a college student who works part-time on top of classes to try and save up money for his future. Masakaki, an employee from the mysterious Financial District gives him a chance to make money in that sort of alternate world, where one's future and potential is used as collateral in "deals", which are essentially battles between two"entrepreneurs". I liked the financial/economic ties, but they were ultimately unnecessary and quite superficial. The impact of the deals and huge influx of money from the Financial District isn't really seen or mentioned until the last few episodes.


Art: Over all, the art wasn't anything special. It never went wonky or anything like that, but it didn't play with any new concepts or exceed my expectations for the average anime, either. The 3D animation occurred at strange times and seemed fairly inconsistent. Masakaki and Msyu switched often between 2D and 3D, which was strange. Some Assets were 2D while others were 3D.


Sound: No complaints. Everything was clear. The OP/EP didn't seem out of place, nor did they seem to fit perfectly, but at least the OP was catchy.


Character: Not so good. Kimimaro is a protagonist that most people will appreciate because he is very average in many facets, but he does a lot of cute things too. At the same time, he is a pretty flat character. There's nothing especially interesting about him that sets him apart from other protagonists in other animes. The supporting characters were also flat and boring, most notably the love interest, Hanabi. I didn't even know that Kimimaro was interested in her until the very end.


Enjoyment: Because this was a short series, it's good for a weekend or a marathon night. It's not especially interesting or engaging, but it's not too boring, either. The unique aspects may pique others' interests in ways that it didn't for me.
I've really enjoyed it, opening was so awesome, I recommend it to watch for people who likes action, a bit of romance, a story about Financial District was like a shot in the bullseye :D :D

C The Money of Soul and Possibility Control has been one of the most enjoyable animes I've watched. I found both the premise of the show and the characters intriguing. However, C suffered from what I felt was a rushed story. 
It tried to fit a story that should have been spread out over 25 episodes into 11. Certain events ( *Spoiler* such as the thinning of the population *Spoiler*) seemed to happen almost immediately when they should have gradually happened over the course of several episodes. This is most apparent when the show skips ahead in the middle of a certain fight scene involvingthe main character.
